repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body: Follow up to #34846 ### Problem Currently, statusline by default doesn't show progress status. ### Solution Add progress-message support to the default statusline. ### How it works Displays statusline text summarizing 'running' progress messages. - If none: returns empty string - If one running item: "title: percent%" - If multiple running items: "Progress: N items avg-percent%" Note: only `runtime/lua/vim/status.lua` is relevant for this pr. Will clean it up after #34846 gets merged. ### Examples

comment_data.body: Note(self): This should fix the test error in channel_spec. However, now since by default vim. status is lazy loaded it doesn't get activated at all by default. Need to figure something out. vim.status should be lazy-loaded. But now the question is what triggers it to activate.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -8729,6 +8729,7 @@ local options = {
           '%<',
           '%f %h%w%m%r ',
           '%=',
+          "%{% luaeval(\"package.loaded['vim.status'] and vim.status.get_progress_status() or ''\") %}",

comment_data.body: Should we auto-remove these over time? Or let them stay forever? What happens if a job gets stuck and the client never lets us know what happened.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,71 @@
+local M = {}
+
+do
+  ---@class ProgressMessage
+  ---@field title string   Title of the progress message
+  ---@field status string  Status: "running" | "success" | "failed" | "cancel"
+  ---@field percent integer Percent complete (0–100)
+
+  ---Cache of active progress messages, keyed by msg_id
+  ---@type table<integer, ProgressMessage>
+  local progress = {}
+
+  -- store progress events
+  local progress_group = vim.api.nvim_create_augroup('nvim.status.progress', { clear = true })
+  vim.api.nvim_create_autocmd('Progress', {
+    group = progress_group,
+    desc = 'Track progress messages for statusline',
+    ---@param ev {data: {msg_id: integer, title: string, status: string, percent: integer}}
+    callback = function(ev)
+      if not ev.data or not ev.data.msg_id then
+        return
+      end
+      progress[ev.data.msg_id] = {
+        title = ev.data.title,
+        status = ev.data.status,
+        percent = ev.data.percent or 0,
+      }
+
+      -- Clear finished items
+      if
+        ev.data.status == 'success'
+        or ev.data.percent == 100
+        or ev.data.status == 'failed'
+        or ev.data.status == 'cancel'
+      then
+        progress[ev.data.msg_id] = nil

comment_data.body:
we have `vim.ringbuf` which can at least set a maximum (could be very high). though it's missing a feature i'd like, which is some sort of hook that triggers when the max is reached, so we can log a message. WIP: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/35464

> What happens if a job gets stuck and the client never lets us know what happened.

if the job is stuck then that implies we also are storing state for the job itself, right? and that's more expensive than this message data.

the general answer is we need visibility mechanisms, such as the ringbuf enhancement i mentioned above, and https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/26861 , etc.

comment_data.body:
> we have vim.ringbuf which can at least set a maximum (could be very high)

If I understand right, `vim.ringbuf` doesn't feel suitable. it's a queue with a max length set at creation, right? We do need map since any item can expire at any time, so the order we remove the items isn't linear. Also,  random access through indexing is also useful for us. 

> if the job is stuck then that implies we also are storing state for the job itself, right? and that's more expensive than this message data.

True, although I wasn't worried about memory uses exactly more like UI getting stale.

comment_data.body: @justinmk anyidea what can be done for this? Reading the conversation on the diagnostinc-status pr and it's followups this seems to be a limiation in our current module system.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -8729,6 +8729,7 @@ local options = {
           '%<',
           '%f %h%w%m%r ',
           '%=',
+          "%{% luaeval(\"package.loaded['vim.status'] and vim.status.get_progress_status() or ''\") %}",

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
  it('shows and updates progress status', function()
```
Why does this get generated separately?  Shouldn't this be part of the function doc? like other functions
Any suggestions for the default format?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -253,4 +253,95 @@ function M._get_urls()
   return urls
 end
 
+do
+  ---@class ProgressMessage
+  ---@field title? string   Title of the progress message
+  ---@field status string  Status: "running" | "success" | "failed" | "cancel"
+  ---@field percent? integer Percent complete (0–100)
+  ---@private
+
+  ---Cache of active progress messages, keyed by msg_id
+  ---@type table<integer, ProgressMessage>
+  local progress = {}
+
+  -- store progress events
+  local progress_group = vim.api.nvim_create_augroup('nvim.status.progress', { clear = true })
+  vim.api.nvim_create_autocmd('Progress', {
+    group = progress_group,
+    desc = 'Track progress messages for statusline',
+    ---@param ev {data: {id: integer, title: string, status: string, percent: integer}}
+    callback = function(ev)
+      if not ev.data or not ev.data.id then
+        return
+      end
+      progress[ev.data.id] = {
+        title = ev.data.title,
+        status = ev.data.status,
+        percent = ev.data.percent or 0,
+      }
+
+      -- Clear finished items
+      if
+        ev.data.status == 'success'
+        or ev.data.percent == 100
+        or ev.data.status == 'failed'
+        or ev.data.status == 'cancel'
+      then
+        progress[ev.data.id] = nil
+      end
+    end,
+  })
+
+  ---Return statusline text summarizing progress messages.
+  --- - If none: returns empty string
+  --- - If one running item: "title: 42%"
+  --- - If multiple running items: "Progress: N items AVG%"

comment_data.body:
Should we show something much smaller?

For example something like
- {avg-percent}%({count})

with 1 item `30%` with two item `28%(2)`

comment_data.body: Personally, I prefer `{avg-percent}%({count})` as it's immediately clear what the count number relates to. In the screenshot in the PR description it was not immediately obvious what 10% relates to as most numbers in statusline do not have space gaps with their labels if present

@@ -4734,6 +4734,23 @@ vim.text.indent({size}, {text}, {opts})                    *vim.text.indent()*
 ==============================================================================
 Lua module: vim.ui                                                    *vim.ui*
 
+*vim.ui.get_progress_status.Opts*
+
+    Fields: ~
+      • {fmt}?  (`fun(running: ProgressMessage[]):string`) custom formater for
+                progress messages
+
+
+vim.ui.get_progress_status({opts})              *vim.ui.get_progress_status()*

comment_data.body: I think `ui.progress_status` is better. This is statusline specific. We can leave `ui.progress` for future use if we need it.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4734,6 +4734,23 @@ vim.text.indent({size}, {text}, {opts})                    *vim.text.indent()*
 ==============================================================================
 Lua module: vim.ui                                                    *vim.ui*
 
+*vim.ui.get_progress_status.Opts*
+
+    Fields: ~
+      • {fmt}?  (`fun(running: ProgressMessage[]):string`) custom formater for
+                progress messages
+
+
+vim.ui.get_progress_status({opts})              *vim.ui.get_progress_status()*

comment_regular_data.body:
`vim.ui` seems appropriate, what is the motivation for a new `vim.status` module ?

Also check if https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/35152#issuecomment-3205352525 has any implications here.

> vim.ui seems appropriate, what is the motivation for a new vim.status module ?

The motivation was to keep all statusline-related stuff together somewhere. But I think using vim.ui is fine.

> Also check if https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/35152#issuecomment-3205352525 has any implications here.

I feel like adding new statusline items adds unnecessary complications. Since it basically involves dealing with the statusline-expression parser. Also if we keep adding new items like that we will run out of letters or will have to settle for suboptimal abbebiation. For example, %p taken so we can't really say p for progress anymore. Using Lua functions makes adding things to statusline significantly easier. If anything, we should provide a better way to run Lua expressions from the statusline.

Populating global/local variables and building a statusline from that isn't bad idea in my opinion. Before neovim and lua got endorsed vim stuff used to work like that. That way still works. And because executing VimL expressions in the statusline is supported and viml can conviniently access those variables statusline integration in that way becomes much simpler. 

I was actually testing setting g:progress_status variable on the event callback yesterday. It basically works almost the same. 


regarding https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/35152#issuecomment-3148714384

We can add something like this here. Let's say I pass the progress-table to the user provided formater. And the currently formating just becomes the default formater for the opreration. Should I try that out?

> The motivation was to keep all statusline-related stuff together somewhere. But I think using vim.ui is fine.

Not sure. I would lean towards putting it in `vim.ui` until we have a clear reason not to. Maybe we need to introduce `vim.msg` for message-related functionality (progress, notifications, ...?).

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: feat(progress): add progress message integration for statusline
